titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Time Inc. Staff Organizations
1940-2015
MS 3009-RG 18
titlestmt.author: Collection processed by Holly Deakyne and Melanie Rinehart
titlestmt.sponsor: The processing of the Time Inc. Records was made possible by a generous grant from the Henry Luce Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-10-31T18:24:34

did.abstract: Time Inc. Staff Organizations contains records from clubs, sports, and other membership organizations involving only Time Inc. staff. The organizations include the Time Inc. Bowling League, Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner (LGTW), and the Time-Life Alumni Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Time Inc. Staff Organizations contains records from clubs, sports, and other membership organizations involving only Time Inc. staff. These organizations were not necessarily sanctioned or overseen by Time Inc., but rather staff-driven. The organizations include the Time Inc. Bowling League, Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner (LGTW), and the Time-Life Alumni Society (TLAS).

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Series II. Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner (LGTW) Records
Series III. Time-Life Alumni Society (TLAS) Collection

accruals.head: Accruals Note
accruals.p: Further additions to this finding aid are expected.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers with the exception of restricted materials. Restricted materials include membership information in Series II. Restricted materials are located in boxes R14. Materials created within the past 35 years also may be subject to restriction on a case-by-case basis. Unreformatted digital material in the collection is not accessible. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. Although the N-YHS owns this collection as physical property, the donor specifically retains all copyright and all other proprietary rights which may exist. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: Holly Deakyne created the collection-level descriptive notes to produce this finding aid.

Series I was processed by Deakyne in 2017. The original folders were retained when present although most documents were loose or in envelopes and required housing in archival folders. Physical arrangement was imposed. Deakyne created the inventory and other descriptive notes for this series.

Series II was processed by Melanie Rinehart in 2017. The original folders were retained although some documents were transferred to archival containers in instances of overcrowding. Physical arrangement was imposed. Rinehart and Deakyne created the inventory and other descriptive notes for this series.

Series III was processed by Melanie Rinehart in 2018. The original folders were retained although some documents were transferred to archival containers in instances of overcrowding. Physical arrangement was imposed. Rinehart created the inventory and other descriptive notes for this series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials Note
relatedmaterial.p: This finding aid relates to just one record group of the Time Inc. Records. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the Time Inc. Records (MS 3009). The Henry Luce Papers (MS 3014) were acquired with the Time Inc. Records. The collection of books acquired with the records are cataloged as the Time Inc. Reference Library. Additional records on Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner are in the Time Inc. Reference Files (MS 3009-RG 3).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Bowling League Records document Time Inc.'s staff bowling league from 1961 to 1971. Based on the records, members in charge at various times were Bud Bliven, Carol-Ann Carpentieri, Joyce Christiansen, Loretta Geissler, Rod McDonald, Mary Piper, Val Pour, and Marian Powers. While teams list both men and women members, there are some records for the Woman's Bowling League from the same time period. Records include lists of participants; certifications and sanctions from the national bowling organizations; invitations and planning materials for league luncheons, awards banquets, and the 25th anniversary; newsletters and flyers; record books containing scores, statistics, and schedules; scorecards; registration sheets; photographic material; a scrapbook; a photograph album; and buttons. The "General" files may contain any of these materials. The newsletter was at one point called b.i.f., which was the motto "Bowling is Fun," and looks styled after the Time Inc. newsletter F.Y.I. The folder "Old Time Inc. Bowlers" includes lists of participants going back to the 1950s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized chronologically by bowling season, then alphabetically by topic or record type. Undated materials are at the end.

scopecontent.p: Photographs are of an event at Mamma Leone's.

did.unittitle: Series II. Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner (LGTW) Records

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized chronologically by year, then alphabetically by topic or record type. Undated materials are at the beginning.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lesbians and Gay Men at Time Warner (LGTW) was a staff grassroots organization at Time Warner from 1990 to 1995. Its goal was to be an "education and support group that addresses workplace issues affecting employees who are lesbian, gay, or bisexual". Later iterations of the group include Out@TimeWarner and Out@TimeInc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Records include advocacy correspondence, meeting agenda, membership cards and contact lists, event planning materials, newsletters, memoranda, news clippings, and reference material. Membership lists and other materials naming members other than the Coordinating Committee are restricted since member confidentiality was assured by the group.

did.unittitle: GLAAD Media Guide to the Lesbian and Gay Community

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes digital material of 1 computer disc (floppy disk) : 3 1/2 in.

did.unittitle: And The Band Played On Script
Time Warner Work & Family Resource Area
Series III. Time-Life Alumni Society (TLAS) Collection

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Organized into five subseries:
Subseries III.A. President's Files
Subseries III.B. Newsletters and Membership Directories
Subseries III.C. Photographs
Subseries III.D. Audiovisual materials
Subseries III.E. General

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Time-Life Alumni Society (TLAS) was founded in October 1977 by several retiring editors as a way to keep former Time Inc. employees connected to Time Inc. and each other after leaving the company. Receiving a small stipend by Time Inc. to print invitations and a newsletter, as well as office space, TLAS used member dues to fund several luncheons with guest speakers per year prior to 2018. Notable members include Dick Stolley, Norm Pearlstine, John Huey, Ralph Graves, and Maureen Dowd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include videocassettes, audiocassettes, photographs, member directories, memos, meeting minutes, newsletters, news clippings, and correspondence. These are records gathered by the Time Inc. Archives from TLAS and do not reflect TLAS's original organizational records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dick Stolley, whose materials from time as TLAS president are included, was an editor at various Time Inc. publications for over 40 years. His most notable moment was when he, as Life magazine editor, negotiated to purchase rights to the Zapruder film of the Kennedy assassination. Materials are dated from 2000 to 2005 and contain materials such as news clippings or personal letters from TLAS members, obituaries regarding past TLAS members, and internal correspondence or memos regarding TLAS activities.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.B. Newsletters And Membership Directories

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The member directories and newsletters range from 1979 to 2015. Newsletters also contain extra souvenir pamphlets from TLAS-sponsored parties or "Travels with TLAS".

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically, then in reverse chronological order within each group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the photographs are of TLAS parties or "Travels with TLAS", which consisted of tours in locations such as Storm King, Paris, and Washington, D.C. One set of photographs, from the now-defunct 1940s employee group Time Out, is from Daniel and Mary Fraser Longwell's personal collection, sent to Marian McDermott in 1978; Daniel helped found Life magazine and was an editor for ten years, and Mary was a chief of research at Time (Prendergast and Colvin 449). Please note this Time Out group is not associated with the later LGBT staff organization.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in reverse chronological, with undated materials at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Videocassettes are recordings of TLAS luncheon presentations and panels. Notable speakers include Hugh Sidey, Dick Stolley, Norm Pearlstine, and Martha Stewart.
The audiocassettes are recordings of TLAS luncheon presentations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by subject of event, then by speakers.
